metadata.title: Mixture Matrix Completion
metadata.author: Daniel Pimentel-Alarcon
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Completing a data matrix X has become an ubiquitous problem in modern data science, with motivations in recommender systems, computer vision, and networks inference, to name a few. One typical assumption is that X is low-rank. A more general model assumes that each column of X corresponds to one of several lowrank matrices. This paper generalizes these models to what we call mixture matrix completion (MMC): the case where each entry of X corresponds to one of several low-rank matrices. MMC is a more accurate model for recommender systems, and brings more flexibility to other completion and clustering problems. We make four fundamental contributions about this new model. First, we show that MMC is theoretically possible (well-posed). Second, we give its precise information-theoretic identifiability conditions. Third, we derive the sample complexity of MMC. Finally, we give a practical algorithm for MMC with performance comparable to the state-of-the-art for simpler related problems, both on synthetic and real data.

highlights: Matrix completion aims to estimate the missing entries of an incomplete data matrix X
Later in 2012, Eriksson et. al. [2] introduced high-rank matrix completion (HRMC), known as subspace clustering with missing data

This paper introduces an even more general model: mixture matrix completion (MMC), which assumes that each entry in X comes from one out of several low-rank matrices, and the goal is to recover the matrices in the mixture
Figure 1 illustrates the generalization from low-rank matrix completion to high-rank matrix completion and to mixture matrix completion

The subtlety in proving these results is that there could exist false mixtures that agree with the observed entries, even if the sampling is uniquely completable for low-rank matrix completion and high-rank matrix completion

To put this under perspective, notice (Figure 2) that this is comparable the amount of missing data tolerated by GSSC [19] and LMaFit [11], which are state-of-the-art for the simpler problems of high-rank matrix completion and low-rank matrix completion
key_statements: Matrix completion aims to estimate the missing entries of an incomplete data matrix X
Later in 2012, Eriksson et. al. [2] introduced high-rank matrix completion (HRMC), known as subspace clustering with missing data
Both low-rank matrix completion and high-rank matrix completion have attracted a tremendous amount of attention

This paper introduces an even more general model: mixture matrix completion (MMC), which assumes that each entry in X comes from one out of several low-rank matrices, and the goal is to recover the matrices in the mixture
Figure 1 illustrates the generalization from low-rank matrix completion to high-rank matrix completion and to mixture matrix completion

The subtlety in proving these results is that there could exist false mixtures that agree with the observed entries, even if the sampling is uniquely completable for low-rank matrix completion and high-rank matrix completion
The columns corresponding to each subnet form a low-rank matrix, which is precisely the model assumed by high-rank matrix completion

The main idea is that mixture matrix completion, like most mixture problems, can be viewed as a clustering task: if we could determine the entries of XΩ that correspond to each Xk, we would be able to partition XΩ

To put this under perspective, notice (Figure 2) that this is comparable the amount of missing data tolerated by GSSC [19] and LMaFit [11], which are state-of-the-art for the simpler problems of high-rank matrix completion and low-rank matrix completion
summary: Matrix completion aims to estimate the missing entries of an incomplete data matrix X.
This more general model assumes that each column of X comes from one of several low-rank matrices, allowing several types of users.

This paper introduces an even more general model: mixture matrix completion (MMC), which assumes that each entry in X comes from one out of several low-rank matrices, and the goal is to recover the matrices in the mixture.
We show that MMC is theoretically possible if we observe the right entries and the mixture is generic.
We provide precise information-theoretical conditions on the entries that need to be observed such that a mixture of K low-rank matrices is identifiable.
The subtlety in proving these results is that there could exist false mixtures that agree with the observed entries, even if the sampling is uniquely completable for LRMC and HRMC.
The columns corresponding to each subnet form a low-rank matrix, which is precisely the model assumed by HRMC.
XΩ contains a mixture of entries from several low-rank matrices.
MMC remains challenging even if the subspaces corresponding to the low-rank matrices in the mixture are known, and even X is fully observed.
If Xk is observed on more than r + 1 entries per column, it suffices that Ωk contains a pattern satisfying the conditions of Theorem 1.
Theorem 2 shows that the sample complexity of MMC is O(K max{r, log d}) observations per column of XΩ.
The main idea is that MMC, like most mixture problems, can be viewed as a clustering task: if we could determine the entries of XΩ that correspond to each Xk, we would be able to partition XΩ
In our simulations we first generate matrices Uk ∈ Rd×r and Θk ∈ Rr×n with i.i.d. N(0, 1) entries to use as bases and coefficients of the low-rank matrices in the mixture, i.e., Xk = UkΘk ∈ Rd×n.

It is quite remarkable that AMMC works most of the time with as little as p ≈ 0.6, corresponding to observing ≈ 0.3 of the entries in each Xk. To put this under perspective, notice (Figure 2) that this is comparable the amount of missing data tolerated by GSSC [19] and LMaFit [11], which are state-of-the-art for the simpler problems of HRMC and LRMC.
MMC brings more flexibility, allowing multiple low-rank matrices to model background, structured foreground objects and illumination artifacts, while at the same time accounting for outliers.
headline: We show that mixture matrix completion is theoretically possible
